text: Psalm 14
The Folly of the Godless and God’s Final Triumph
For the \add music\add* director. Of David.\f + \fr Ps 14 \ft The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm \f*
\add The\add* fool says in his heart, “There is no God.”
They are corrupt.
They do abominable deeds.
There is none who does good.
Yahweh looks down from heaven upon the children of humankind
to see whether there is one who has insight,
one who cares about God.
All have gone astray;
they are altogether corrupt.
There is not one who does good;
there is not even one.
All who do evil—do they not know,
\add they\add* who eat my people \add as though\add* they were eating bread?
They do not call on Yahweh.
There ⸤they are very fearful⸥\f + \fr 14:5 \ft Literally “they feared a fear” \f*
because God \add is\add* with \add the\add* generation of \add the\add* righteous.
You would put to shame \add the\add* plan of \add the\add* poor,
because\f + \fr 14:6 \ft Or “but” \f* Yahweh \add is\add* his refuge.
⸤Oh that from Zion⸥\f + \fr 14:7 \ft Literally “Who will give \fq that \ft from Zion” \f* \add would come\add* salvation \add for\add* Israel!
When Yahweh returns the fortunes of his people,
Jacob will rejoice; Israel will be happy.
